reviewText: This review is for all my card playing and/or match 3 loving friends.\n\nHanafuda, a traditional Japanese card, is well hard to describe.  It is like a combination of Go Fish, Old Maid, Bridge, Whist, Gin Rummy, Poker, Eucre, and Cribbage.  Instead of 13 cards in only 4 suits, there 4 cards per season or month with the added bonus of special higher point sets of 3 to 5 cards.  It is a bit confusing a first, I admit, but there is an in-game visual guide to the card hands.  Plus before beginning any card matches or tournment matches there is a very informative tutorial about how to play.  It also helps that your playing cards become highlighted along with the central pot" cards to help find matches.  This card game is very challenging."
voteText: 44 of 49 people (90%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I've only just recently got this game but I saw it had no reveiws so I wanted to spread the love. If your playing becuase you just want to try it out, saw it in an anime movie(Summer Wars), or just becuase, its a great start to teach you how to play the game of Koi Koi. Its pretty bare basics with a bit of a learning curve (mostly with just remembering which card is which and what ones go into a pair), but by played a few rounds you can quickly pick up the basics to the game. If your looking for a different kinda card game to play I defintaly recomend Koi Koi.

The music is good and it fits the pace of the game, and the coms in quick play are not brutal. I havn't tried the collection mode but I assume it'll work like a tournument getting harder each round. The cards all look really nice and the game also looks nice. The only thing is the lack of a exit button if your in full screen mode. An online multiplayer option would make the game perfect.

Otherwise really fun and worth the money to play if you like Japanese card games/dont mind a learning curve! :) KOI KOI!!

reviewText:
Frankly there are better Flash versions of Hanafuda Koi-Koi that are completely free on the web. This version is extremely basic for the ¬£6.99 price tag.

There are very jarring animation issues - for example when cards are dealt from the stack they disappear and appear elsewhere on the board, rather than moving from the stack to the new position. This is extremely jarring even for experienced players. The same is true when you match a card, the card begins to move in one direction and then just disappears and pops up elsewhere.

There's also no way to turn off the 'hint' mode (which highlights matching cards on the board when you hover over a card in your hand). This is pretty frustrating for advanced players and will cause lazy/bad habits in new players.

Nor are there any difficulty settings, so whether you're a beginner or an expert you get the same experience.

The game only offers two modes Full Screen" or "Windowed" - you cannot resize or set the resolution of either mode. The windowed mode is rather small on a large resolution display.

'Yaku'
date: 'Koi Koi' and 'Stop' overlays cannot be skipped and take too long to display which will make each game longer than it needs to be.\n\nThe main reason I'm being so particular in this review is that for ¬£6.99 I would expect a more polished experience. Compared to other versions of this game (on iOS
hoursPlayed: Windows 8 Store or even on the web) the game is lacking in polish and I recommend getting your Hanafuda fix elsewhere."

reviewText:
This is a very, very basic hanafuda game.
For a start the interface and feel of it is very amateurish. Stills are nice, but once things start go get in motion... I confess before this game, I never would have thought you could fail at animating cards moving over a board.
There is also the odd artistic choice on cards here and there, and the omnipresence of the English language, even if you set the game to Japanese.
There is of course no multiplayer, because who plays with real people?
Even against an automated opponent, the pacing of the game is pretty bad on fast setting, with scoring being handled by individual banners for each trick, one after the other - if you are familiar with the game, you know this can happen dozens of time in a big hand game.
Then, and this one is a deal-breaker : there is the glaring absence of any (really, any!) rule customization. They are all hard-set, and you better be glad with them.
The AI is also pretty stupid, not attempting to reverse a loss on the final month of a game, and stopping early.

You can get better, for free. And you can get infinitely better, for a small fee, on any phone or tablet.

Also, the boob-fishing on the game's Steam banner? Not awkward at all, and very classy!

reviewText: A very faithful rendition of Koi-Koi with a fairly smart A.I. opponent. The UI and presentation is about as beautiful and simplistic as the Hanafuda deck itself. You can jump in for a match instantly with Quick Play or try Collection Mode, which is a sort of campaign" like mode where you choose a region of Japan and face an opponent in a game of Koi-Koi. The main focus of this mode is to collect postcards that depict beautiful photographs taken in the region you chose previously.\n\nOverall
recommended: and that's all you really need a game like this to be. It's presented in a lovely way and there's even a tutorial for new players. The game goes as far as highlighting possible matches for yakus
hoursPlayed: and even a complete list of both the cards and yakus for you to look over at a glance.\n\nIf you are new to Koi-Koi and are interested in learning to play it
voteText: or a long time fan of the age old playing card game

reviewText:
NOTE: Played a lot offline so low playtime!

Having self taught this game to myself and a group of friends, I have a good perspective on this game to the majority of people only playing this card game for the first time.

Positives:
1) Good Clean UI and very helpful card highlighting
- Memorising which card matches with which is abit hard for many people (November especially) and this game allows you to play without having to memorise, which is great for getting players right in.
2) AI is fierce
- A problem this game might have face would be an AI that just matches cards randomly but as far as I have seen the AI has been great so far. It capitalises on you being greedy and punishes you for it a lot.
3) Brilliant Tutorial
- I made slides to teach this game to my friends. This game has it all written down and the limits of the what moves you can make and identifying the Yaku immediately helps it with beginners a lot. I think anyone looking to learn Hanafuda should start with the game.

Negatives:
1) House Rules?
- The game at one stage said the game is played accross Japan with house rules and It would be GREAT if they had that here, especially with their collection mode which honestly needs a bit of more substance for it to have more replay value.
2) Multiplayer
- This game badly needs this for the game community to expand. I have actual Hanafuda cards so I can get by without it but having this multiplayer function would be brilliant for this game.
3) One Trick AI
- The AI is great and all but its play has little variance. Gets Yaku, 2 cards left? Stops. Gets 3 Brights? Chances are, stops. I have played with my friends and seen ridiculous draws like throwing down a Chrysanthenum card to only pick up a sake cup that just flipped open into double viewing combo (Moon, Sakura and Sake Cup). I don't see the AI having the balls to do that. I know making AI is hard but having some variance in AI, like one that plays more safely, another that plays aggressively will add so much depth into this game.

Looking at the collection mode, I feel that the game missed some chances to make it a Brilliant game because having all those individuals across Japan you can play against might be like some AI gauntlet with each with local house rules or differing AI. That would have been a strong feature that adds a lot of replayability but overall I love when traditional games like this get to see the light of day on Steam and gain a wider audience. Overall, I would reccomend this game to people who like traditional games that have a lot of luck involved but also a bit of skill.

reviewText:
I bought this as an alternative to learning the game. I found the online rules very confusing and even with Online Flash Games i still struggled to understand the basic rules of the game!

I understood there were hands to collect, that each card had months pertaining to each flower set and that there was a points system that I didn't understand.

This game solved everything, sure its simple but its worth the ¬£6 price tag, it functions as you would expect a real game so the replayability is just as replayable as the real life version, just with less cursing when you steal a set from someone!

I used this as a learning tool, from the overlay that shows you each month and their card  flower sets and the Hands you could make with the sets that you could constantly check as you play so its less of a struggle! Not to mention as it was released the devs made sure as to fix up all the problems they've encountered meaning the game becomes stable, no doubt it was fixed very quickly as well!

I doubt there'll be extra content because of the game itself can only go so far.

Tl;Dr If you want to learn? Worth it. If you know the game? worth it.

reviewText:
I admit I probably only got started playing this game because of anime film Summer Wars, and ever since watching it I've wanted to play the card game and now I can thanks to Steam!

It's an interesting, kind of addictive card game where you have to score points (or Yaku) using certain combinations of cards. I was kind of uncertain about how to play as the tutorial explains extreme basics of the game and not much else, but after playing a few quick games against the computer opponent you soon learn what's good and what's not.

The only way I can think to explain it to someone who has never played is it's a little like the  'snap' where you have to match playing cards, only instead of matching a 5 of a suit to another 5 of a suit you have to match flowers/trees of the month to other flowers/trees of the same month to collect cards (So 4 cards/flowers of 12 suits/months) and instead of matching your cards to your opponents, you match them to a selection of cards in the center of the play area. However, matching cards  doesn't mean you get points right away like you would if you were playing snap where you just have to get the most cards to win. Heck you could get points at the start of a round, only to lose them to the opponent at the end of the round. The points system is kind of like a tug of war, and it can go either way.

When you get a point-scoring combination of cards you get the option to say 'Koi Koi!' (Come on!) to your opponent. If you (or you opponent) call Koi Koi the music picks up the pace adding to the sense of... I want to say 'urgency' but I'm not sure that's the word I want... But it becomes a lot more fast-paced at least. Saying Koi Koi can mean more points to be won, but also more points to be lost, so it's  a bit of a gamble whether you carry on or not, but I find that's half the fun. Saying no to calling Koi Koi ends the round there.

It does take a bit of learning for the Yaku cominations, and maybe even for the months of the cards when choosing the dealer for the game, but it's quite fun when you learn it. I was terrified at first because I didn't know any of the months or what flowers or combinations would work, but at the top of a game screen you can click on the 'Cards' or 'Yaku' at any time and look at them. Not only that, but even if you don't look at those and you start a game, if you have any cards that match with the ones in the middle they're highlighted, and it's a helpful feature.

I've only played the Quick Game part of Koi Koi, I haven't tried the Collection mode, so I can't comment on that, but I like what I've played so far.

This is probably more for those who have an interest in Japan, but if you also have an interest in card games, it might be worth a look at. I'd probably give it an 8/10

reviewText:
Koi-Koi is a fun and well made card game. You can think about it like a mini Mah-jong as each turn you try to grab cards to make a combo and get points (or rather steal points from your opponent). And like in Mah-jong, you start don't understanding what to do, for like 2~3 games, and then you start to see what combo you could do, and it gets really enjoyable, and addictive. The AI is quite good (a tad shy on the koi-koi but it's playing wisely, not like me).

The game is a faithful adaptation of the actual card game, the visuals are very nice, and the music is relaxing, even when it accelerate a bit after a koi-koi. So far,  the game only miss a local multiplayer [and a voiceover when you do a koi-koi like the objection ! in Phoenix Wright...].

I definitely recommend it for anyone wanting a simple and well made but addictive game !

reviewText:
A great intro to the game of Koi-Koi.

The rules may seem daunting at first. The tutorial is alright, but because of the sheer amount of info (you're learning to play a new card game after all), much of it actually flies over your head even if you're paying attention. But when you start to play the interface lights up matching cards, which makes it easier especially for beginners.

After you get the hang of matching cards is when the real game begins. The AI is clever and is seriously trying to form the right cards, and will mercilessly beat you whenever possible.

Graphics are simple and clean, sound is alright. Music is traditional, which is perfect.

It has a sort of career mode called Collection mode" where you challenge players from different regions to collect postcards.

All in all
date: great fun if you have the patience and determination to learn it. It's not hard especially with the UI helping you out. But yeah. Practice with this video game version if you ever wanna try playing Koi-Koi IRL. I imagine it'll be great fun against a real person."

reviewText: A good way to learn the card game. The tutorial is well done, the UI is effective, and the musics are good, but there's only a few. There's not much different game modes, it's only about playing games from scratch vs the AI. No multiplayer, no challenges, no variant of the rules, only a mode where you can unlock pictures. The 'AI' is correct, but it's definitely not a real AI, it's rigged, and you'll often face the luckiest man in the world, but sometimes it'll be at your advantage, given the 'AI' is unable to stop at the right moment (If he stops, he wins the match, but he continues). But it's working and looks normal 'most' of the time. A good buy if you want to relax few minutes from time to time and learn how to play a game with the Hanafuda cards.

reviewText:
If you like card games, this is a rewarding purchase.

As others have noted, it plays like a mish mash of other games. Poker, Go Fish - etc. Even so, it has its own style and play.

Your first couple of plays will be daunting. There is a short learning curve to conquer before you are winning any hands. But don't get discouraged - it is much easier than it appears.

Begin by memorizing the various plant types and winning hands. The game has a small Wiki of sorts to make this easy. Googling will also show you what cards match with what - seasons and flowers. There are some cards that are must haves - such as a cup can be slotted into several hands. The easy hands to win are hands with recognizable cards - the harder hands require memorizing banners.

It is possible to learn everything you need from the tutorial and the ingame wiki, but YouTube has some videos and there are plenty of informative sites out there.

Give it a shot.

If you have conquered poker and other favorites - this is a great game to add to your collection.

reviewText: I really enjoy this card game. reviewText:
I enjoy playing hanafuda as a way to relax, but this game is moreso boring than soothing. The music is soothing though, and I would rather listen to it to relax than play.

The interface is nice and smooth. Simplistic, at best. Granted, there is no way to turn off the animations that are within the game. When you leave the window, the game ends up being at a standstill. So, if you think you can play while multitasking... It won't work. There is no option to fix this within the game settings either.

Playing in either Quickplay or Collection mode, there isn't a significant difference besides collecting postcard images in Collection mode. So there really isn't much to go on. There isn't a change of difficulty either. So you're just playing a very linear game through and through.

When playing, you are stuck with mouseover hints and, if you accidentally click on a card where there are two options.... there are no take-backs. You HAVE to play that card. There is also no way to skip in-game animations either. So sometimes the game feels a bit stretched out than it should.

As others have said, it is a very basic hanafuda game and, for the price of $10, you may as well play it as a free flash game or get a free version for your mobile device. So even if you pay for the mobile versions, those at least give you a bang for your buck. To the very least, there are some of those that have a multiplayer option.

reviewText:
The game and its presentatino leave much to be desired.

If you've never played Hanafuda, be ready for a game that has a heavy amount of luck built in. While there is room for strategy, it's heavily outweighed by random chance. The game essentially boils down to a match-2-or-more, and the second half of each turn top-decks a card to match against the ones on the board. It was common to have no good moves an entire round, just because of how cards were dealt.

OK, so Koi-Koi Japan didn't invent Hanafuda, and shouldn't be punished for it. Still, I give a thumbs down. The tutorial was abrupt and jumped around quickly. The game only supports one resolution and stretches it to fill a 1080p window.

The game may have only been a buck, but it led mostly to frustration.

reviewText: A hanafuda game, although basic, it is fun. Bought the game in a steam sale as it cought my attention. The game is a deck of 48 cards with 3(?) cards for each month of the year.  The goal is to get as many card sets as possible befor your opponent to get points.\nAs a first time player I found the tutorial to be simple enough to follow, what  I didnt pick up in the tutorial, I did in a couple of quick-play rounds after. One thing that I think was a little bit of a downer is that there is no two-player option if you where/are wanting to play with a friend (also no online multi-player).\nAll in all the game was woth the money I spent on it.

reviewText: I have very much enjoyed my time with Koi-Koi Japan. I do agree with the negative review below that says the card movement is a bit choppy but gameplay is still solid. There are so few retail hanafuda games in English, I can only think of the minigame in the Yakuza series on PS3 offhand, so to be able to just boot this up and play is great. reviewText:

I would have been happy to pay ¬£1-¬£3 for this, so for 69p it's a no-brainer.
Also note that at the time of writing this is the only Hanafuda game on Steam.

Despite the simplicity this is a very fun game.
Admitedly the tutorial isn't very good, but once you start actually playing the game it's fairly easy to pick up as you go.
The graphics are quite pretty, the animations are nice and the music sets a nice atmosphere.

It is unfortunate that there's no multiplayer option, but that is by no means a deal-breaker.

reviewText: Having no idea how to play this game at all going into it, I have to say this game is awesome. Great tutorial, and the game doesn't overcomplicate things. You can handily reference all the different ways to earn points at any time during the match, which is helpful when beginning to not only know how to earn points, but also how to stop the AI from doing so. It's extremely tempting to risk all your accumulated points for the round when you get a good hand...I didn't expect to enjoy this game as much as I did! Definitely recommended, too bad there's no online multiplayer...
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Was interested in Hanafuda card game and after having to see it in the Steam Store on special discount (90% !!), I knew I have to get it.

The GUI is very simple to navigate and there's a short tutorial that guides you on how to play the game. Well, for beginners like myself, it is not easy to know and memorize all the cards combination required to win the game. You just have to play many times to get an idea how to go about. While winning is the main objective, it is crucial to know what cards to play even if your hand isn't good, to prevent your opponent from winning.

There are two game modes aside from Tutorial -- Quick Play and Collection Mode. In Collection Mode, there is a map of Japan divided in 8 areas where you get to play against the person of each area. Winning a match will get you a postcard from the area; each area has 5 postcards to collect, which is essential for achievement.

While the game can be rather repetitive, it is fairly enjoyable. The DLC Enjoy Pack is currently free to download (as per the special discount offer) and consists of a new guide character, various Fuda designs and in-game BGM. It would have been better if the DLC included more challenges, difficulty and achievements.

reviewText:
Edit: Waifu displayed in the banner is available in the free DLC 'Enjoy pack', otherwise you only get silhouettes in wafuku

It's a pretty decent version of Koi-Koi, with nice graphics and great music (by decent, I mean most Yaku is integrated correctly). It takes a while to get used to the staccato animation (cards are animated when moving to your table, but not animated when they are placed on the board).

So far there are no rules customization, which I would like to see (in future updates perhaps?)

It's advertised as 'Optimized for Hanafuda Beginners', and it really is for beginners, the difficulty is not that hard. Veterans of Koi-Koi would be disappointed I guess. But it's great as a relaxing style Solitaire game :)

Also, you get achievements for assembling the different yaku!

I'd give it a solid 4/5, if more features like rule customization or customizable AI difficulty was present, I'd give 5/5~

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A great traditional japanese card game. It's simple to learn, but the more you play it, the more you understand how to make the best decisions.

Basically you're trying to form suits (Yaku) that provide a variety of points. But you can only match cards into your suits if there's a corresponding card type on the field, if you can't match cards then you'll need to put down the card on the field, which you will be able to use next turn (Or your opponent might snatch it before it gets there.). So sometimes, if a opponent has almost a complete suit, and you know that your opponent might be waiting for a certain type to go onto the field, then you'll just avoid playing that 1 card so that your opponent might need to discard the card that he requires and you could take it for yourself.

It's a bit hard to understand but, if you play it just try to learn the Yaku and through experience you'll understand what type of yaku need to be matched with what cards. Each card type has a season/month related to it, and you can only match cards with the same seasons. If you play it, you'll understand it.

Best 1 euro you can spend on steam!

P.S Even though there's a anime girls picture on the game logo, there's nothing anime related in the game itself.

reviewText: On the whole, this is fun, and worth the 99 cents I paid for it in the Steam winter sale. I'd go as far as to say that it would have been worth it had I paid up to $2.49 for it. The full price of $9.99, on the other hand, would've been too much. It's not THAT good.\n\nWhile the AI appears to be competent with regard to deciding which cards to play, it's not as good on deciding whether to koi-koi. As a previous reviewer noted, it appears not to take the overall point standings into account at ALL, leading to spectacularly poor decisions in the final round of a match. (But then I'm not that great a player, and I like winning, so maybe I shouldn't complain about this.) A choice of AI strengths, and some options regarding rule variants, would've been nice.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
If you ever find yourself in a situation where a self-aware artificial intelligence has decided to test Earth's population and then destroy everyone by dropping a satellite upon the planet - and the only thing preventing the world's certain destruction is your ability to distract the AI by winning a game of Hanafuda (so you can buy your new boyfriend enough time to solve the complex algorithm that unlocks the satellite's security systems and powers it down) - you will want to make sure you're well versed in both the rules and necessary skills.

This is the area in which Koi-Koi Japan will come in handy.  It teaches you how to play Koi-Koi.  It allows you to practice against various AI's.  It plays a competant game of Hanafuda.  The only thing it doesn't do is provide you with a kimono-clad VR avatar.  But Oculus Rift is not out yet, so there's still time.

So, I will ask...  what is the fate of the world worth to you?  $1?  You never know when this might come in handy.
